channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹562 â€” July 16, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

ğŸ”’Â The FIPS 140-3 Go Cryptographic Module â€” FIPS 140 is a standard for cryptography implementations thatâ€™s a requirement in certain subsectors (particularly involving the US government) and while most developers wonâ€™t need to worry about it, FIPS 140 support will open doors for some Go devs. This post goes into depth about Go's FIPS 140 support, but if you donâ€™t know what FIPS 140 is, donâ€™t worry about it tooÂ much.

Valsorda, McCarney and Shoemaker

Fix Slow Postgres Queries with pganalyze Query Advisor â€” Register for our webinar July 30 to learn how to detect common Postgres query plan problems, get actionable rewrite recommendations, and track the impact in one comprehensiveÂ tool.

pganalyze sponsor

A Deep Dive Into Deeply Recursive Go â€” Goâ€™s lack of tail-call optimization makes deep recursion prone to fatal stack overflows. Juho discusses real-world recursion scenarios (and the CVEs they led to) and offers ways to make things safer in your code, along with a proposal to add recoverable overflow handling in theÂ runtime.

Juho ForsÃ©n (Mattermost)

Learn Go with Tests: An Online Book for Learning TDD with Go â€” Itâ€™s had a few updates over the past year and remains a fantastic resource for walking through both the basics and more intermediate topics like reflection andÂ generics.

Chris James

ğŸ‡«ğŸ‡· There's now also a French translation, if that's more your tasse de thÃ©.

You Don't Need testify/assert â€” An alternative approach for tight, clean tests, which leads to Antonâ€™s Be minimal test assertions package that follows his ownÂ advice.

Anton Zhiyanov

Kubernetes Best Practices 2025: Comprehensive White Paper â€” Learn how to improve Kubernetes security, reliability and cost control with practical guidance from real-worldÂ clusters.

Fairwinds sponsor

ğŸ“„ Doing Web Things with CGIs is Mostly No Longer a Good Idea â€“ A sensible response to a fun post we featured last week about using Go to create modern-day CGI-styleÂ apps. Chris Siebenmann

ğŸ“„ Building Event-Driven Go Apps with Azure Cosmos DB and Azure Functions Abhishek Gupta (Microsoft)

ğŸ“„ A Zero-Sized Bug Hunt in golang.org/x/sync Fillmore Labs

ğŸ“„ New in Go 1.25: WaitGroup.Go() Christoph Berger

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

pproftui: A Terminal-Based Diagnostic Tool for pprof Data â€” The idea is rather than focusing on profiling data visually, you get a quick view into the actual code causing the activities beingÂ monitored. You can then fix problems more quickly and diff the results of future runs. Live profile viewing is alsoÂ possible.

Oloruntobi1

oapi-codegen 2.5: Generate Go Boilerplate from OpenAPI 3 Specs â€” A tool and library for converting OpenAI specifications to Go code, both server and client-side. Less boilerplate for you to write! The v2.5 release notes tease some new tweaks and eventual OpenAPI 3.1 support (which you can use some tricks to achieve forÂ now).

Various Contributors

Introducing go-cdc-chunkers: A New Way to Chunk and Deduplicate Everything â€” Content-Defined Chunking (CDC) is the idea of dividing data into variable-sized chunks based on the content of the data, making it easier to deduplicate. Gilles explains why thatâ€™s useful (in quite some depth) and shows off a new Go project giving access to suchÂ algorithms.

Gilles Chehade

cpuid 2.3: CPU Feature Identification for Go â€” Use this to find out how many physical and logical cores there are, the family of CPU, and similar details. Supports x86/x64 andÂ ARM64.

Klaus Post

  • FastHTTP 1.64 â€“ Performance-oriented alternative to net/http for specific high-volumeÂ scenarios.

  • Revive 1.11 â€“ Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter forÂ Go.

  • FerretDB 2.4 â€“ MongoDB-a-like but atop Postgres (orÂ SQLite).

  • gocryptfs 2.6 â€“ Encrypted overlayÂ filesystem atopÂ Go-FUSE.

  • BadgerDB 4.8 â€“ Fast Go-powered key/valueÂ database.

  • Kubo 0.36 â€“ An IPFS implementation in Go

item.title: ã€200 million requests per day with Go and cgi-binã€‘GOå’ŒCGI-binæ¯å¤©2äº¿è¦æ±‚
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹561 â€” July 9, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

What's //go:nosplit For? â€” Go has many comment-based directives for tweaking inlining, stack checks, write barriers, and more. Many arenâ€™t well documented, but can have striking effects, such as nosplit which can offer a performance boost in certain scenarios, but may also lead to faults or a locked runtime. This is, nonetheless, a fantasticÂ explainer.

Miguel Young

Generic Interfaces â€” Axel presents the idea that as interfaces are types themselves, they too can have type parameters. He shows how this lets you write one core implementation of a binary search tree and support built-in, callback-based, or method-based comparisons, before moving on to deeper concepts. There's a lot to get your teeth intoÂ here.

Axel Wagner

Build Containers from Scratch â€” Start with raw Linux tools like chroot, namespaces, and cgroups to truly understand how containers work. Then build your own with Docker and deploy them usingÂ Kubernetes.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • â­ Go 1.25 Release Candidate 2 has beenÂ released.

  • Socket's Sarah Gooding fleshes out the recent story that there's an official Go SDK for MCP (Model Context Protocol) under development.

  • From Go 1.25 onward, Microsoft's build of Go will have telemetry enabled byÂ default.

  • ğŸ¤– Imagine a filesystem that's really just an LLM making stuff up: Andrew Healey's implemented this spine-chilling idea in Go as a mountable FUSE filesystem.

  • GitLab has caught a supply chain attack targeting Go developers through a fake MongoDB driverÂ module.

Serving 200 Million Requests Per Day with cgi-bin â€” CGI was commonly used in the earlier days of the Web to have HTTP requests launch backend processes and return the results. Over time we moved onto persistently-running apps, but could the speed of Go and launching processes in 2025 make cgi-bin viable again? Yes! (But you might not wantÂ to..)

Jake Gold

â–¶ï¸ How I Recreated Shazam's Algorithm from Scratch â€“ A fun look at implementing a music detection algorithm from scratch. Go does the heavy lifting and thereâ€™sÂ source. Chigozirim

ğŸ“„ An Optimization and Debugging Story with Go and DTrace Philippe Gaultier

ğŸ“„ Developing a Terminal UI in Go with Bubble Tea â€“ Good high levelÂ advice. Alex Pliutau

ğŸ“„ Am I Online? â€“ An interesting way to see if your app is truly online by checking a special GoogleÂ URL. Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

doWM: A Tiling and Floating Window Manager for X11 â€” A fast, lightweight window manager written entirely in Go. Youâ€™ll need to be proficient with Linux, however, but this could be a great gateway into tweaking something that feels right for you. GitHubÂ repo.

BobdaProgrammer

ğŸ•¹ï¸Â GORE: A Pure Go Minimal 'Doom' Implementation â€” A few months ago we linked to doomgeneric, an initial effort to transpile 1993â€™s Doom to Go. This cleans it up a lot, makes it more â€œGo-ishâ€ and platform agnostic, and.. it can even render the game on theÂ terminal!

Andre Renaud

Effortless Go Contract Testing: Inferred Automatically FromÂ Traffic â€” Stop hand-crafting brittle contracts. See how they can be inferred from real traffic and updated as your Go APIsÂ evolve.

Signadot sponsor

go-ytdlp: yt-dlp CLI Bindings for Go â€” yt-dlp is a popular audio/video downloading tool â€“ not just for YouTube but hundreds ofÂ platforms.

Liam Stanley

Minimock: A Tool to Generate Mocks from Interface Declarations â€” Generates statically typed mocks and helpers, is fully integrated with the testing package, and supportsÂ generics.

Juno Inc.

Lox: A Lexer and Parser Generator for Go â€” Inspired by ANTLR at the surface level (combined parser and lexer, action code separated from grammar) but more similar to yacc internally (LR(1), dependency-freeÂ parser).

dcaiafa

  • ğŸ¤– Mods 1.8 â€“ Charm's pipelineable AI CLI client, now with MCPÂ support.

  • Hugo 0.148 â€“ The popular Go-powered static site generator. Beware of some breakingÂ changes.

  • MCP-Go 0.33 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP).

  • OpenFGA 1.9 â€“ Google Zanzibar-inspired authorizationÂ engine.

  • GoReleaser 2.11 â€“ Build/release binaries for multipleÂ platforms.

  • pgroll 0.14 â€“ Zero-downtime, reversible, schemaÂ migrations.

  • sh 3.12 â€“ Shell script parser, formatter, andÂ interpreter.

  • fzf 0.64 â€“ Popular command-line fuzzyÂ finder.

ã€‘

yt-dlp CLI Bindings for Go â€” yt-dlp is a popular audio/video downloading tool â€“ not just for YouTube but æ•°ç™¾ä¸ªå¹³å°ã€‚

Juno Inc.

çš„Lexerå’ŒParser Generatoråœ¨åœ°é¢çº§åˆ«å—ANTLRçš„å¯å‘ï¼ˆç»„åˆè§£æå™¨å’ŒLexerï¼Œä¸è¯­æ³•åˆ†å¼€çš„åŠ¨ä½œä»£ç ï¼‰ï¼Œä½†ä¸ yacc å†…éƒ¨ç›¸ä¼¼ï¼ˆLRï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ï¼Œä¾èµ–æ€§parserï¼‰ã€‚

item.title: ã€1 million chess boards and 10,000+ Go binariesã€‘100ä¸‡ä¸ªå›½é™…è±¡æ£‹æ¿å’Œ10,000å¤šä¸ªäºŒè¿›åˆ¶
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹560 â€” July 2, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

An Interactive Tour of Go 1.25 â€” Release Candidate 1 is out, RC2 is expected next week, the draft release notes already make for good reading, and things are on schedule for a final Go 1.25 release in August. What awaits us? Anton presents one of his usual interactive tours packed with code examples you can edit and run from yourÂ browser.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ In a post to golang-announce yesterday, David Chase noted that releases of Go 1.25 RC2, Go 1.24.5 and Go 1.23.11 are due nextÂ Tuesday.

The Evolution of Caching Libraries in Go â€” The developer of the Otter caching library looks at the history of caching libraries in Go, problems developers have had to overcome, and why Otter came intoÂ being.

Alexey Mayshev

Fix Go Bugs and Bottlenecks Fast with AppSignal â€” AppSignal gives Go developers the tools they need to fix bugs, track performance issues, and ship with confidence. Easy to set up, a joy to use, and built for teams that care about their code. Start your free trial today, no credit cardÂ required.

AppSignal sponsor

â™Ÿï¸Â Running a Million-Board Chess MMO in a Single Process â€” A surprisingly thorough explanation of how a game developer put together a large scale multiplayer chess game, with Go not skipping a beat on the backend. The developer also recorded a YouTube video all about it. Iâ€™m not sure about Black or White but this is certainly a win for GoÂ Blue.

Nolen Royalty

ğŸ˜…Â (Ab)using Channels to Implement a 3D Pipe Game â€” Mischief awaits! If channels can be used as conduits for values, why not use them to implement pipes in a game? UhÂ oh..

Jun Rong Lam

How to Manage Configuration Settings in Go Webapps â€” There are many ways to pass configuration to an app (CLI parameters, environment variables, config files), and which one is â€˜rightâ€™ comes down to your preference and app needs. Alex explains each way along with hisÂ preferences.

Alex Edwards

ğŸ“„ Using Flags for Discoverable Test Config â€“ An exploration of different ways to conditionally enableÂ tests. Redowan Delowar

ğŸ“„ Why Go Rocks for Building a Lua Interpreter Roxy Light

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

ğŸ¨Â Colorspace: Color Space Conversion Library â€” Implements different color space logic to allow for conversions and interpolation of colors. Covers sRGB, linear sRGB, CIE XYZ, OKLAB andÂ OKLCH.

Patricio Whittingslow

Cross-Compiling 10,000+ Go CLI Packages Statically â€” The tale of building a large number of Go CLI tools as static binaries using the Zig toolchain. Why? To make life easier for folks who donâ€™t have the Go toolchain installed. An interesting, unconventionalÂ approach.

Ajam / Package Forge

Depot Ships Gocache v2 for 4x Faster Go Builds â€” Bundling cuts thousands of network calls down to hundreds. Massive wins for Go builds in CIÂ environments.

Depot sponsor

ğŸ¤–Â MCP Go SDK: Official Go SDK for Model Context Protocol (MCP) â€” Itâ€™s very early days for this project, enough so that itâ€™s considered â€œunreleasedâ€, but a stable version is expected inÂ August.

Go MCP SDK Authors

ktea: A Bubble Tea-Powered Kafka TUI Client
Jonas Geiregat

  • Anubis 1.20 â€“ Provides a proof-of-work challenge to 'weigh the soul' of incoming HTTP requests in an attempt to stop/slow down AIÂ crawlers.

  • Validator 10.27 â€“ Value validations for structs and fields based onÂ tags.

  • Gofakeit 7.3 â€“ Random fake data generator. Now with ISBNÂ support.

  • Chroma 2.19 â€“ General purpose syntax highlighter in pureÂ Go.

  • Mockery 3.5 â€“ Mock codeÂ autogenerator.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€Go 1.25's JSON evolutionã€‘èµ°1.25çš„Json Evolution
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹559 â€” June 25, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

JSON Evolution in Go: From V1 to V2 â€” A good look into the practicalities of using the JSON v2 package which lands in Go 1.25 (final release due in August) with new field tags, updated marshal defaults, streaming APIs, and other niceties. Highlights include joined custom marshalers and up to 10Ã— fasterÂ unmarshaling.

Anton Zhiyanov

Finding Performance Problems by Diffing Two Go Profiles â€” Goâ€™s pprof profiling tool can show the difference between two profiles to highlight where one run slowed down. Dolt used it to pinpoint a wrongly hard-coded parameter that forced expensive system-tableÂ generation.

Zach Musgrave (DoltHub)

Fullstack without Frameworks â€” Maximiliano Firtman combines vanilla JavaScript and Go to create high-performance apps from scratch. Follow along in this video course and learn more about web components, dynamic client-side routing, authentication, logging and everything inÂ between.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Cloud66's Go Stack in 2025 â€” One Go team shares a little background to its packages of choice, covering configuration management, CLI framework, HTTP framework, ORM, and dependency injection and lifecycleÂ management.

Khash Sajadi

How to Store Go Pointers from (Go) Assembly â€” Goâ€™s assembler is an interesting, deep part of the Go toolchain for writing low-level routines and interfacing directly with Goâ€™s runtime. Few Go developers need to go this deep, but itâ€™s handy to have such aÂ writeup.

ğŸ‘€ New and Quirky Projects

A few projects have appeared on our radar recently which aren't necessarily things you'd introduce into your own apps but which you might find interesting or fun:

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ SSHTron (above) is a multiplayer Tron-style 'lightcycle' game that runs over SSH. You can run it for yourself or try ssh sshtron.zachlatta.com and see if anyone else isÂ around..

  • Mochi is a small embeddable language targeting AI and agentic use-cases that compiles to bytecode that runs on a VM built in Go.

  • Dizer is a custom DNS server written in Go. Its homepage even breaks down most of the source code so you can more easily understand how itÂ works.

  • GUItignore is a Web-based tool for creating .gitignore files covering one or more dev ecosystems of your choice, includingÂ Go.

  • Parser is a new Go library for filtering slices of structs using an SQL-like queryÂ language. We hope to feature this again as it progresses, it looksÂ cool.

  • lazycontainer is a new BubbleTea-powered 'fancy terminal UI' for Apple Containers, as currently in macOS TahoeÂ Beta.

  • AGL (AnotherGoLang) is a Go-esque language that compiles to Go.
